title: Fort Union Trading Post National Historic Site: Park Home
body: The Grandest Fort on the Upper Missouri River   Between 1828 and 1867, Fort Union was the most important fur trade post on the Upper Missouri River. Here, the Assiniboine and six other Northern Plains Indian Tribes exchanged buffalo robes and smaller furs for goods from around the world, including cloth, guns, blankets, and beads. A bastion of peaceful coexistence, the post annually traded over 25,000 buffalo robes and $100,000 in merchandise.                Rendezvous 2014 Reenactors    Rendezvous living history reenactors and fort volunteers pose in front of the Bourgeois House.        Unearthing the Past, Discovering Today   How was the fort built and from what materials? Archeologists needed to unearth the answers before the fort could be accurately rebuilt.        Historic Overview of Fort Union   Built at the request of the Assiniboine nation, Fort Union quickly emerged as the Upper Missouri's longest lasting trading post.
